We believe in one God, the Father Almighty, creator and originator, from whom every fatherhood in heaven and on earth is named. And in His only Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, who was born from the Father before all ages, God from God, light from light, through whom all things were made in heaven and on earth, visible and invisible. He is the Word, the wisdom, the power, the life, and the true light, who in the last days became incarnate for us, was born of the holy Virgin, was crucified, died, and was buried. He also rose from the dead on the third day, ascended into heaven, and sits at the right hand of the Father. He will come at the end of the world to judge the living and the dead and to repay each according to their deeds, with a kingdom that endures forever. He will be at the right hand of the Father, not only in this world but also in the future. And in the Holy Spirit, the Comforter, whom He promised to the Apostles after He ascended to heaven, sent to teach them and remind them of everything, through whom the souls of those who sincerely believe in Him are sanctified.

One. But those who say: The Son is from nothing, or from another substance, and not from God; and that there was a time or age when He did not exist: the holy and catholic Church knows them to be strangers.

Two. If anyone says that the Father and the Son are two gods: let them be accursed.

Three. And if anyone, saying there is one God, does not confess that Christ, the God before ages, was the Son of God obedient to the Father in the creation of all things: let them be accursed.

Four. And if anyone dares to say that the unborn God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary: let them be accursed.

Five. And if anyone says that the Son is from Mary according to foreknowledge or predestination, and not born from the Father before ages, and through whom all things were made: let them be accursed.

Six. If anyone says that the substance of God expands and contracts: let them be accursed.

If anyone claims that the Son of God is a spread-out substance or refers to the width of His substance as the Son, let them be cursed.

If anyone describes the Son of God as an implanted or spoken word, let them be cursed.

If anyone says that the Son born of Mary is merely a man, let them be cursed.

If anyone suggests that God and the man born of Mary perceives God as unbegotten in this manner, let them be cursed.

If anyone hears The Word became flesh (John 1:14) and believes the Word was transformed into flesh or took on flesh through change, let them be cursed.

If anyone hears that the only Son of God was crucified and claims His divinity experienced corruption, suffering, change, diminishment, or death, let them be cursed.

If anyone interprets Let us make man (Genesis 1:26) as not being spoken by the Father to the Son, but rather that God spoke to Himself, let them be cursed.

If anyone argues that the Son was not seen by Abraham (Genesis 18), but instead the unbegotten God or a part of Him, let them be cursed.

If anyone claims that Jacob did not wrestle with the Son as a man (Genesis 32:24), but with the unbegotten God or a part of Him, let them be cursed.

If anyone does not interpret The Lord rained from the Lord (Genesis 19:24) as referring to the Son and the Father, but believes He rained from Himself, let them be cursed. For the Lord the Son rained from the Lord the Father.

If anyone calls the Lord and Lord, Father and Son (since the Lord from the Lord), two gods, let them be cursed. We do not equate the Son with the Father or compare them but understand Him as subordinate. For He did not descend into Sodom without the Father's will; nor did He rain from Himself, but from the Lord, by the authority of the Father; nor does He sit at the right hand by Himself, but hears the Father saying, Sit at my right hand (Psalm 110:1).

If anyone claims the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are one person, let them be cursed.

If anyone refers to the Holy Spirit as the paraclete and claims He is the unbegotten God, let them be cursed.

If anyone, as the Lord taught us, does not recognize that the Advocate is distinct from the Son, for He said, "And the Father will send you another Advocate, whom I will ask" John 14:16, let them be cursed.

If anyone claims that the Holy Spirit is a part of the Father or the Son, let them be cursed.

If anyone asserts that the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are three gods, let them be cursed.

If anyone interprets the words, "I am the first God, and I am the last God, and besides me, there is no God" Isaiah 44:6, in a way that undermines the only-begotten God before the ages, let them be cursed.

If anyone claims that the Son is created by the will of God as if He were merely a part of creation, let them be cursed.

If anyone says that the Son was born against the will of the Father, let them be cursed. For the Father was neither compelled against His will nor driven by necessity to beget the Son when He did not desire to. But as soon as He willed, He showed that He begot Him from Himself, without time and without suffering.

If anyone claims the Son is unbegotten and without beginning, suggesting two without beginning, two unbegotten, and two uncreated, making two gods, let them be cursed. For the Head, which is the beginning of all, is the Son; the Head, which is the beginning of Christ, is God. Thus, we refer all things to the one who is without beginning, the beginning of all, through the Son.

And again, affirming the understanding of Christianity, we say that if anyone does not acknowledge that Christ is God, the Son of God, existing before the ages and serving the Father for the perfection of all things, but claims that from the time He was born of Mary, He was named Christ and Son, and began to be God, let them be cursed.

The many deceptions of Photinus are refuted.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The Son is not different from the Father in substance or time. As the situation evolved, those gathered found it necessary to provide a more detailed explanation of faith, addressing multiple questions. This was because the heresy revived by Photinus was attempting to infiltrate the Catholic Church in various subtle ways.

This was done so that every form of pure and unblemished faith could stand against each type of heretical deception, matching every affirmation of faith to the opportunities for treachery. Following that comprehensive explanation of the sacraments, the foundation for explaining faith against heretics began here.

But those who claim that the Son comes from nonexistence, or from another substance and not from God, and that there was a time when he did not exist, are considered outsiders by the holy and Catholic Church.

What room is there for ambiguity here? What remains of the conscience of sincere faith? The Son is not from nonexistent things, ensuring he does not have an origin from nothingness. He does not originate from any other substance except that of God, so nothing else is inherent in him but all that is of God. Since he does not originate from nothing, he does not derive his existence from elsewhere.

He does not differ in time, making the Son timeless with the Father. Therefore, everything is inseparable between the unbegotten Father and the only-begotten Son, as the equality in time, through the very sameness of the existing Father from whom the nativity is derived, does not distinguish them in essence.

If anyone claims that the Father and the Son are two gods, let them be accursed.

And if anyone, while professing there is one God, does not acknowledge that Christ, before the ages, as the Son of God, obeyed the Father in the creation of all things, let them be accursed.

Just as they are one in essence, they are also one in the kind of essence. The devout profession of the name provides us with complete understanding of these matters.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
It's important to understand that while it's wrong to claim the Father and the Son are two separate gods, it's also incorrect to deny that the Son is God. So, when discussing two gods, we exclude the idea of different substances that are separate from each other. There's no other essence besides that of God the Father, from which the eternal Son of God is born. Although we must acknowledge God the Father and proclaim Christ, the Son of God, as God, recognizing two gods is considered irreligious. They can only be one in essence because their essence is singular.

If anyone claims that the unborn God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary, let them be anathema. The Son and the Father are not the same person. This contradicts those who say the Son only existed before Mary through predestination. To prevent heretics from saying the unborn God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary due to differences in the named essence of the Father and the Son, a decisive judgment was made that whoever confesses this is anathema. The unity of the name, based on the essence of an undifferentiated nature, doesn't eliminate the personhood of the begotten essence, so the substance of the one unique God is understood through the unity of the name. The name of both essences, that is, the one God, is proclaimed because of the indistinguishable substance of their undifferentiated nature.

If anyone says that the Son existed only through foreknowledge and predestination before Mary, and was not born of the Father before all ages, and that all things were made through Him, let them be anathema.

The Son of God, our God of all, before being born in the flesh, is understood not to exist according to foreknowledge and predestination, rather than according to the essence of His existing nature. This is due to the Father's foreknowledge, as He predestined Him to exist at a specific time, specifically to be born of a virgin. He was announced to us, rather than existing from eternity in the substance of divine nature. All the things He spoke through the prophets about the mysteries of His incarnation and passion were spoken by the Father according to the foreknowledge about Him. Therefore, the perversity of this doctrine is condemned, which claims that the only-begotten Son of God is known to us, born from the Father before all ages, and creating the ages themselves with all creatures, rather than predestined to be born.

If anyone says the substance of God can expand or contract, let them be anathema. Expansion and contraction do not apply to God. Neither is the Son an expansion of divine substance. Contracting and expanding are physical experiences, but God, who is spirit and moves as He wills, does not expand or contract Himself through a change of substance. Remaining free beyond the necessity of physical nature, He provides what He wills, when He wills, and where He wills, from Himself. Therefore, it is impious to attribute a change of substance to such a great power's freedom.

If anyone says that the Son makes the substance of God expand, or calls the breadth of His substance the Son, let them be anathema. The previous statement, even if it intended to teach about the unchangeable God, set the stage for this subsequent heresy. For some have dared to extend the unborn God up to the holy Virgin by an expansion of substance, suggesting that the breadth drawn out by a certain aspect of His nature, assuming man, might be called the Son. Nor was the Son, perfect God before all ages, later born as man. The whole of this the Catholic faith condemns, in which the Father is said to be changeable, and the born Son is denied.

If anyone says the Son was born unwillingly by the Father, let them be cursed. chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The same voice can be misinterpreted in three different ways.

When we say the Father and the Son are of one substance, implying they exist separately yet are one and the same under two different names:

we must not think of the Son as merely a name without acknowledging this unity, if we claim the same unique and singular essence for both the Father and the Son.

This misunderstanding can lead to the idea that the Father is divided from himself, separating a part of himself as the Son.

Heretics often assert this by claiming one substance, and they find our confession appealing because it can be vague and lead to error.

Another error suggests that when we say the Father and the Son are of one substance, it implies a prior substance from which they both derive equally:

thus suggesting three entities: one substance and two inheritors of that substance.

Just as two co-heirs share an inheritance that existed before them, two equals might appear to share a prior substance.

However, asserting a single substance for the Father and the Son might imply:

either one entity with two names, or a divided substance creating two incomplete substances, or a third prior substance used by both, thus called one because it was split into two.

In this case, where is the concept of birth? How do we understand the Father and the Son if they are seen more as a division or sharing of a prior substance rather than a natural birth?

With such significant dangers to faith, we must be careful with our language;

so that what is understood piously is not spoken impiously, and an innocent conscience does not become guilty due to heretical interpretations.

When a Catholic speaks of one substance of the Father and the Son, he should not begin with this concept:

nor consider it the most crucial aspect, as if without it, true faith cannot exist.

When people claim there's a difference between similarity and equality, I ask where this equality originates. If the Son is similar to the Father in essence, virtue, glory, and time, I question why he isn't considered equal. This was established in the early faith as a condemnation: anyone who claims the Father has a different essence from the Son should be cursed. If, then, he did not give a nature different or dissimilar to the one he begot without passion, he could have only given his own essence. Thus, similarity is a property, property is equality, and equality makes no difference. What makes no difference is one; not by union of person, but by equality of nature.

The same virtue exists in both the Son and the Father. Even though, both by common sense and divine authorities, it's understood there's no difference between similarity and equality, since according to Moses and John, the Son is both similar and equal to the Father: let's see if the Lord, when the Jews were upset because he called God his Father, thereby making himself equal to God, actually taught that he is equal to God. Or does homoousion mean anything other than the essence of the two is one and the same, according to the nature of their origin, because the essence of the Son is not from elsewhere? Since it isn't from elsewhere, both are rightly believed to be of one essence; because the Son's substance comes solely from the Father's nature.

Should homoousion be dismissed because it is often misunderstood? On the contrary, is it argued that it should be rejected because of this misunderstanding? If we fear misunderstanding, should we also remove what is written in the Apostle: "There is one mediator between God and humans, the man Christ Jesus" (First Timothy chapter two, verse five); because Photinus uses it to support his heresy: and should it not be read by us because he misinterprets it?

Should we let the letter to the Philippians be destroyed, either by fire or erasure, lest Marcion misreads it: "And being found in appearance as a man" (Philippians chapter two, verse seven), claiming it's a fantasy rather than the reality of the body? Should the Gospel of John not exist, lest Sabellius learns from it: "I and the Father are one" (John chapter ten, verse thirty)? And should those now saying that Christ is a creature not write: "The Father is greater than I" (John chapter fourteen, verse twenty-eight)?

Should those who argue that the Son is unlike the Father avoid reading: "But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father" (Mark chapter thirteen, verse thirty-two)? Should the books of Moses not exist, lest darkness be seen as co-eternal with God, who dwells in unapproachable light; because in Genesis, chapter one, verse two, day follows night: lest Methuselah's years surpass the age of the flood (Genesis chapter five, verse twenty-six), and not only eight souls are saved (First Peter chapter three, verse twenty).

Should God, hearing the outcry of the Sodomites whose sins are complete, descend as if unaware of their transgressions, to see if their sins match the outcry, and God seems not to know what He already knows (Genesis chapter eighteen, verse twenty-one)? Should we also not know the tomb of Moses, buried by those who laid him to rest (Deuteronomy chapter thirty-four, verse six)? Should these, as heretics believe, suggest that the law itself is contradictory and adversarial? And because these are not understood by them, should they not be read by us?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If it seems necessary, let them also perish-though I don't mean this lightly, but because of the necessity of the response-all those divine and holy Gospels of human salvation. This ensures they don't contradict each other in their statements. So that the Lord, about to send the Holy Spirit, is not read as having been born of the Holy Spirit himself. And when he is about to announce death by the sword, he doesn't indicate to buy a sword as he is about to suffer. For instance, in Matthew chapter twenty-six, verse fifty-two, as he is about to descend to the dead, he is not with the thief in paradise, as mentioned in Luke chapter twenty-two, verse thirty-six.

So that finally, the apostles are not found guilty. They were commanded to baptize in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, as stated in Matthew chapter twenty-eight, verse nineteen, yet they baptized only in the name of Jesus, as mentioned in Acts chapter ten, verse forty-eight. To you, Brothers, I speak with a voice for those who are no longer nurtured with milk but are strong with solid food, as noted in Hebrews chapter five, verse twelve.

Is it because the wise of the world do not understand these things, and they seem foolish to them, that we will be wise with the world by believing these foolish things? And because these things are blind to the wicked, will we not shine with the truth of the understood doctrine? It is wrongly judged against holy things if, because they are not considered holy by some, they should not exist. Therefore, let us not glory in the cross of Christ, because it is a scandal to the world, nor preach death in the living God, lest God be accused of being dead by the wicked.

Eighty-six. Or because it was rejected by eighty bishops, the term "homoousion" is misunderstood. What does it matter to me who understands it well? The Samosatene confessed "homoousion" wrongly, but did Arius deny it better? Eighty bishops rejected it long ago, but recently three hundred and eighteen accepted it. Indeed, to me, that very number is sacred here, in which Abraham, the victor over impious kings, as mentioned in Genesis chapter fourteen, verse fourteen, is blessed by him who is the form of the eternal priesthood.

Those who rejected the heretic did not also prove against the heretic? The authority of the ancients is weighty; is the holiness of these also light? If they felt contrary things to each other, we ought to judge and approve the better. But if by approving and disapproving they established one thing both ways, why do we overturn what has been well established?

Did Hosius, who was present at Nicaea, decide that silence was necessary? Perhaps someone might argue that some of those at the council back then believed silence was needed regarding homoousios. Reluctantly, I must ask: Did they not also decide that silence was necessary about homoiousios? I beg you, let no one other than the old man Hosius, who excessively cherishes his own solemnity, think that silence is necessary about either. Where will we find ourselves amid such heretical madness if we fail to maintain either by not accepting both? It cannot be considered impious to say that if neither is found written, neither should be confessed, or both should.

What does Hilary understand by homoousios? Concerns about homoousios arise. I understand homoousios, holy men, as God from God, not of dissimilar essence, not divided, but begotten, and from the substance of the unbegotten God, a single-begotten nativity in the Son, according to similarity. This understanding was greatly confirmed for me by homoousios. Why do you condemn my faith in homoousios, which, through the profession of homoiousios, you cannot help but approve? You condemn my faith, or rather your own, when you criticize its understanding in the name. But does someone else misunderstand it? Let us collectively condemn faulty understanding, not remove the security of faith. Do you think we should adhere to the Synod of Samosata to prevent anyone from misappropriating homoousios according to the understanding of Samosata? Let us also subscribe to the council of Nicaea, so the Arians do not disapprove of homoousios. But is there a fear that, according to faith, homoousios might not signify homoiousios? Let it be determined that they are of no difference, of one and similar substance. But can homoousios be misunderstood? Let it be established how it can be understood correctly. We wisely agree on one and the same thing; I ask that what we agree on is holy among us. Forgive me, Brothers, as I have often asked: You are not Arians; why are you considered Arians by denying homoiousios?

Homoiousios is not without offense.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Homoousios-You might say: The ambiguity of homoousios disturbs me. Again, I urge you to listen without being troubled: the simplicity of homoousios concerns me. Often, things that are similar can be misleading. I worry about gold leaf because it might mislead me, though it appears like gold. I am cautious of milk's appearance, wondering if the milk offered to me is not sheep's milk but resembles cow's milk. For sheep's milk to truly be sheep's milk, it must come from a sheep. True resemblance lies in the truth of nature. However, the truth in the nature of both does not deny homoousion. This is indeed likeness according to essence, if a mass similar to another mass isn't deceptive, and if milk of the same color doesn't differ in taste. Nothing can resemble gold unless it is gold; it can't resemble milk unless it's of the same kind. The color of wine has often misled me, yet taste revealed it to be a different liquid. I have seen meats that look alike, but taste later revealed their different natures. I am wary of these similarities that don't stem from the unity of nature.

Faith of Ancyra Secretly Sent to Sirmium by Some.-Indeed, Brothers, I fear the heresies of the East emerging at various times: and what I express fear about, I have already read. In what you, as delegation ministers accepted with some Orientals' consent, brought to Sirmium for subscription, there's no room for suspicion: but initially, there was a significant amount of offense, which I believe you, most holy men Basil, Eustathius, and Eleusius, kept quiet to avoid scandal. If these matters were written correctly, they should not have been kept silent. However, if they are now silent because they weren't written correctly, we must ensure they aren't mentioned later. For now, I'm holding back from discussing these matters: yet you agree with me that not all the faith written at Ancyra was the same. I'm not speaking of rumors; I have the testimony of letters, not from laypeople but given by bishops.

Exhortation to Accept homoousion.

He first heard the Nicene Creed just before his exile.

I urge you, brothers, to cast aside suspicion and eliminate any chance for it.

To affirm the homoousion, let us not dismiss the homousion. Let's think of all the holy and resting priests: what will the Lord judge about us if we now condemn them? What will become of us, who bring this to the point where, because they were not bishops, we also have not truly begun? After all, we were ordained by them, and we are their successors.

Should we renounce the episcopate because we have assumed its office from something condemned? Forgive my sorrow, brothers, but what you dare is impious. I cannot bear the thought that the homousion, according to a religious understanding, is condemned. The name itself holds no crime, as it does not disrupt the essence of faith.

I neither know nor understand homoeusion, except from the confession of similar essence. I testify to the God of heaven and earth that even when I had heard neither, I always understood both to mean the same through homousion and homoeusion: that nothing can be similar to itself by nature unless it is of the same nature.

Having been reborn long ago and remaining in the episcopate for some time, I only encountered the Nicene faith when I was about to be exiled. However, the understanding of homousii and homoeusii was revealed to me through the Gospels and the Apostles. What we seek is pious. Let us not condemn the fathers, nor embolden heretics, lest while we label something heresy, we inadvertently foster it.

Our fathers interpreted the nature of homousii devoutly after the Nicene Synod, and books exist as testament, with conscience intact. If anything needs further explanation, let us consult together. A strong state of faith can be established among us, ensuring that well-founded beliefs remain secure and those poorly understood are not dismissed.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
I have stepped forward, dear brothers, setting aside the shame of human conscience and forgetting my humility, to write about these great and hidden matters.

Driven by my love for you, I feel compelled to address issues that have remained unspoken and unaddressed until now.

I have shared what I believe, knowing it is my duty to serve the Church, to make the voice of my episcopate in Christ known through these writings, in accordance with the teachings of the Gospels.

It is your responsibility as a community to discuss, anticipate, and take action to ensure that you preserve with a religious conscience what you have faithfully maintained so far, and hold on to what you already possess.

Please remember my exile in your holy prayers: I do not know whether, after explaining this faith, returning to you in the Lord Jesus Christ will be as joyful as the security of dying.

I wish that God and our Lord keep you untainted and unharmed until the day of revelation, dear brothers.
